sections.name: Bugaboo

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.html:
After devouring enough souls, a bogey transforms into the more powerful and sophisticated bugaboo.

Recall Knowledge - Fey (Nature): DC 24

sections.name: Bogeyman
Bogey Origins

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.html: While bogeymen stem from bugaboos and bugaboos from bogeys, it is unknown where, exactly, bogeys come from. If superstitious storytellers are to be believed, then bogeys arise from the unfortunate victims kidnapped by bogeymen. According to these tales, victims go missing for months or even years before returning as bogeys to the town they once called home.

sections.name: Epidemic of Terror

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.html: Bogeymen and their lesser kin delight in instilling fear in small communities where gossip can quickly amplify their shadowy deeds. In such locales, bogeymen use peoples’ natural tendency to spread misinformation to sow discord and escape notice—for who would rightfully believe that an actual bogeyman is behind the latest murder?

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.html: Bogeymen are stealers of innocence and devourers of souls. Few targets who survive an encounter with them remain unchanged. Different names are given to bogeymen according to their varying sizes and degrees of power, which typically advance as the monsters consume more souls.

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

traits.name: Uncommon
traits.text: Something of uncommon rarity requires special training or comes from a particular culture or part of the world. Some character choices give access to uncommon options, and the GM can choose to allow access for anyone. Less is known about uncommon creatures than common creatures. They typically can’t be summoned. The DC of Recall Knowledge checks related to these creature is increased by 2.

traits.name: Evil
traits.text: Evil effects often manipulate energy from evil-aligned Outer Planes and are antithetical to good divine servants or divine servants of good deities. A creature with this trait is evil in alignment.

traits.name: Fey
traits.text: Creatures of the First World are called the fey.

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

traits.name: Agile
traits.text: The multiple attack penalty you take with this weapon on the second attack on your turn is –4 instead of –5, and –8 instead of –10 on the third and subsequent attacks in the turn.

traits.name: Finesse
traits.text: You can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier on attack rolls using this melee weapon. You still use your Strength modifier when calculating damage.

traits.name: Magical
traits.text:
Something with the magical trait is imbued with magical energies not tied to a specific tradition of magic. A magical item radiates a magic aura infused with its dominant school of magic.  
  
 Some items or effects are closely tied to a particular tradition of magic. In these cases, the item has the arcane, divine, occult, or primal trait instead of the magical trait. Any of these traits indicate that the item is magical.

ability.name: Devour Soul

traits.name: Necromancy
traits.text: Effects and magic items with this trait are associated with the necromancy school of magic, typically involving forces of life and death.

traits.name: Occult
traits.text: This magic comes from the occult tradition, calling upon bizarre and ephemeral mysteries. Anything with this trait is magical.

ability.requirement: The bugaboo has killed a creature within the last round and is adjacent to the creature
ability.effect: The bugaboo consumes the creature’s soul. The soul is utterly destroyed—nothing short of wish or a similar effect can restore it to life, and only after the bugaboo has been slain. The bugaboo regains Hit Points equal to double the level of the consumed creature. After devouring six souls within a year, a bugaboo transforms into a bogeyman.

ability.name: Mobility
ability.text: When the bugaboo uses a Stride action to move half their Speed or less, that movement does not trigger reactions.

ability.name: Sneak Attack
ability.text: The bugaboo deals 1d6 extra precision damage to flat-footed creatures.

ability.name: Striking Fear

traits.name: Emotion
traits.text: This effect alters a creature’s emotions. Effects with this trait always have the mental trait as well. Creatures with special training or that have mechanical or artificial intelligence are immune to emotion effects.

traits.name: Fear
traits.text: Fear effects evoke the emotion of fear. Effects with this trait always have the mental and emotion traits as well.

traits.name: Mental
traits.text: A mental effect can alter the target’s mind. It has no effect on an object or a mindless creature.

ability.critical_failure: The target is frightened 3 and fleeing for 1 round.
ability.text: If a bugaboo scores a critical hit with a claw Strike, the target must attempt a DC 24 Will save.

ability.name: Surprise Attack
ability.text: On the first round of combat, creatures that haven’t acted yet are flat-footed to the bugaboo.
